answers.answer: How is he doing in school?  If he is finding it hard to cope all day long that would make anyone feel exhausted and could account for the agression and anger as well.  Is he is a mainstream school?  Do staff has experience of expertise of Aspergers.  Is he the only child in his school with this diagnosis.  Does he find it hard/easy academically.  What are his social skills like.  Does school have dinnertime clubs or allow him access to the library or IT room during breaks?  Has the school put together any kind of circle of friends to help support him etc.

My son is the same and I think it is the school day. Some days he is not able to do any homework and I leave him be. He then spents time on his bed reading comics but some days I make him go out and get milk from the shops or something like that and he is fine afterwards. It is very difficult to find the right balance of allowing complete withdrawal and making him do sth to catch him from falling into depression as he doesn't really know himself what makes him feel like that and what is going to make him feel better...

This may sound very strange, but have you had him tested for Type 1 diabetes? My son was the exact same way, and although he has AS, he is also a newly dx diabetic.We found out he was aggressive because his sugar was sky high and didn't really notice the tiredness, until he really didn't want to do anything. By the time I caught it, his blood sugar was in the thousands and his A1C was 14.9! He was hospitalized immediately and put in ICU.I don't mean to be alarming, but sometimes even though it's the farthest from your mind, it's better to be safe than sorry.
